author: BatMeckley
content: Wishing everyone a happy happy holidays, no matter whether you have a Grammy, whether you give great advice or objectively bad takes, whether you’re tall, short, or in between, whether you’re Irish, or from somewhere better, no matter which holiday you celebrate, whether you post here or just lurk to soak up the great information, whether you’re Matt Rad who put this all together or Cian who tries to burn it all down, I love you all and wish health, happiness, and prosperity for you and your families. 💙🎄

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'd like to say thank you to @everyone here. It's no overstatement to say that you *are* this server and the reason for it's success.

We've got a very special community that's been built up over our short history and this place would fall apart if each and every one of us wasn't maintaining the level of excellence, understanding, kindness, and great discourse that this place is known for. We've got something special here.

I love to see how welcoming you all are whenever we get someone new and how helpful we are at answering the questions of people at every stage of their journey. Hats off to the collective "we" and to the individuals who make this place great.

And finally, thank you to @oaklandmatt for creating such a place. Thank you for everything that you've made here and for giving us a place to thrive and come to know one another.

author: austenballard
content:
as we say around these parts, 

Hello my friends! 

I'm so stoked to share with you the VERY FIRST edition of ***Live With Matt Rad Community Profiles***, a new article series in which I will be writing pieces on members of our community. And who better to begin with than our esteemed Discord Admin, Mr. Bradley Will?

https://lwmrblog.carrd.co/

I hope you enjoy this and future pieces to come. Thanks very much to @Slow Hand and @oaklandmatt for letting me take this project on and share it with you all.

author: cian riordan
content: FYI @everyone -- tomorrow is @oaklandmatt's bday -- but he's in Australia, so it *might* be today? Well either way, HBD you old goat! Here's an oldie of you taking me over a surdo drum:

author: BatMeckley
content:
Look, its 15 minutes to midnight, so I’m going to get this out of the way early:

Happy birthday Cian Riordan. I had to be friends with Matt Rad for YEARS and was convinced that nothing good was ever going to come from it. And then, because of that friendship, and that unspeakable endurance, I got to meet you. And then I no longer had any doubts: no, nothing good is going to come from that friendship. 

Happy 49th my dude. You’re a giant in my eyes.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Been working on this MPC Studio all day today, and was struck by how lucky I am to be a part of this server. Last night I had a question about an audio routing program and multiple people that are not on my payroll, they do not work for me or owe me anything, responded not just same day but within minutes with information that helped me get to where I was trying to go.

So many producers/writers/engineers/music makers/ dreamers are going to be better off, and way further along their paths, because of the wealth of knowledge and the generosity of the people on this discord, from the most seasoned mods to the newest noobs. And it’s entirely free. 

Thanks @oaklandmatt for putting this thing together. There’s always something new to learn and this is a rad place to learn it.

content: Just want to say it's been so cool to get to know so many of ya'll on this channel and hear work you've done and chat in depth, there's SO much talent and amazing perspectives on this channel and it's made a huge difference in my life since it's existed. thanks @oaklandmatt for making this community happen.

author: austenballard
content:
Y'all I am half dead, fresh out of hospital and fully nuked off medications so please forgive the frankness and possible incoherence, but 

I just want to take a moment to appreciate the quality of discussion that happens in this server, and really thank each and every one of you, @oaklandmatt , @admin, @moderator, and everyone else for contributing to what is fast becoming one of my favorite places on the internet.

I made a post like this a few months ago when I first joined this server after stumbling across LWMR and Conversations, but it bears repeating that the extent to which this is a hidden gem, an oasis in the desert of the Mixdown Industrial Complex is truly remarkable.

Personally things have been rough af lately and it's been a joy to be able to read and participate in so much insightful, informative and stimulating conversation here, and has really helped keep my spirits up. I think it's probably a similar experience for a lot of folks in here. 

So thanks, all of you, and since it was just Lunar New Year I'd like to say here's to a great year of the rabbit to all.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Lotta gratitude for this watercooler/university of a community. Thanks @oaklandmatt for collecting such an eclectic group of creatives.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Sigh… here goes.

Professionally, I legitimately think I’ve learned a new technique or plug in or even way of approaching something EVERY SINGLE DAY im on this discord. The wealth of knowledge on here is staggering, and one of the coolest things about music is you never beat the game; everyday there’s a new technique or something to learn. And I genuinely think there’s no better place to learn more (mostly) bullshit free information than right here. 

Personally, I’ve met truly great and meaningful friends through this whole clusterfuck that I will undoubtedly carry with me as I get even older and even greyer. (Like literally, I have to carry Cian around in one of those little baby bjorn things when he gets antsy). 

One of @oaklandmatt superpowers is his ability to size up what people are great at and then pair them with other people that will utilize and magnify those skills. Honestly one of the lesser talked about but more important parts of being a real producer. Grateful for all of ya.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I dreamt last night that Eric Valentine turned out to be a hacky, big on YouTube but where are his credits type character. 

He'd leveraged the LWMR discord to sell 1,200 tickets to a 1 day masterclass type event, and had drawn all these people out to a field where he'd set up a huge marquee but no PA.

When the session started, he had a projector showing his screen but it was too small, and nobody could hear what he was talking about, or what he was playing back from his laptop speakers. At the lunch break, a single intern was serving unidentifiable yellowish slop to a huge queue of people on cheap paper plates. The people in the queue were all disappointed but trying to remain positive.

In the queue, Eric walked past grinning, and when I asked how he was doing, he said "can you believe it? I'm making $200 an hour today!!". 

Given everything I'd heard from @cian riordan and @oaklandmatt, I really expected more of Eric.

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
Still feel relatively new having only joined at the back end of 2023 but it’s fucking NUTS how much I feel like I’ve progressed since being here.

The generosity of time and spirit from so many of you is what makes it so distinct as a community. No barriers, no snobbery, just openness, a love for exploring new things and a feverish spirit to make the best shit possible. I’ve already made some good buds on here too which makes it even better. 

Thank you @oaklandmatt, mods and all the other contributors for all of it including those who are in my DMs with wisdom and advice.

PS I’m going full-time in 2 weeks with my music work and a large part of my confidence in doing so has come from the crew on here. Big love to all of you and long may it continue.

author: Barbara
content: Jumping in to thank @oaklandmatt, all mods 🫶 and contributors for creating and maintaining an healthy online space that's accessible to anyone who wants to learn more and to participate in this community (which, IMO, is particularly important for folks who don't get the opportunity of sharing their questions, experiences, failures, success, learning journeys,... on a regular basis with other colleagues). This is a very special corner on the internet for me, and I swear that everytime I read your convos (even the ones I don't interact with) I always take something new with me (a new approach, a bit of inspiration, some insight on how to deal with different situations) and feel grateful for everything that is shared. So, here's to more of this 🥂

author: cian riordan
content: Damn was just about to respond to this but Francesco just nailed it with that PDF. Second everything he said in there. I remember for Matt's traps we did 18" wide with 1 1/2" thickness of fiberglass... which was the largest we could source at the time. I remember Eric had ones that were wider... maybe even 24" or 30" wide. The different dimensions will obviously resonate at different frequencies. In all of my room tuning adventures with Eric, we found that a combination of several different sizes will help narrow out the low end.

author: Zack Hames
content: I think the fact that you’re reflecting on it is meaningful. The reality is, for a lot of artists, we may be their first recording experience, their first record, etc and they’ll grow a LOT during and move on and grow. I think this was mentioned In the Conversations podcast. So for me sometimes it’s letting certain things go that aren’t going to change in someones performance and trying to make it work. I did a pretty emo influenced record recently, and the vocalist isn’t the best. I tried to give him tons of vocal tips and train him the best I could, and it ultimately made it so much harder to record him because it sounded so unnatural and unemotional. We ended up using a lot of earlier scratch takes for certain songs (and they feel super good/relatable/captivating even though it’s maybe nasally) and then using particularly emotional driven takes at the very end. I think there’s a balance of being honest/giving feedback and being delicate/not destructive in your response. Also, @oaklandmatt , your point about learning 10 different ways to say something needs to be better, is spot on.

I Think @cian riordan (not entitet sure) and @oaklandmatt had a conversation on how theyve learned to deal and live within this aspect of the job, and had some great insights.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
@Adam Thein @oaklandmatt I finally got around to running Adam’s hell test. M1 bossed it like a beefcake, so I went troubleshooting on my template plugins.

Main culprit for shitness was  was native Antares (AT Pro and EFX). Swapped them out for the UAD versions of Access and Real-time, now working perfectly. Only issue is they top out DSP when there are heaps of stacks.

author: peterlabberton
content:
K, so, I’m not a mastering engineer, and I know that’s not exactly the focus of this group, but I’m curious to hear some of the most experienced folks on here (i.e. @cian riordan @oaklandmatt and I’m sure others I don’t know about!) chime in on loudness in 2021. For instance, I love love love Jaime by Brittany Howard, and Shawn is phenomenal (AND if shit sounds great who cares what the LUFS meter says), but it is loud as hell. With streaming theoretically leveling the playing field a bit, what are you guys looking for when you get a record mastered? Is there someone mastering right now who is just boldly NOT slamming a limiter and letting things breathe more? Do we care?

I ask partly because, like I think many people, I incorporate a limiter on my mix bus to get things loud and be mixing “into” a mastering chain, and this has led me down a bit of a rabbit hole.

author: peterlabberton
content:
@oaklandmatt I haven’t watched that, I’m late to the party here! 🤦🏻‍♂️

I guess my question is more like... since we know streaming services are turning stuff down to *some* extent, whatever that is, are there any people actually taking advantage of it, or are the waters still just too murky to make any kind of move on a major release? And it sounds like they’re still too murky.

author: chris_donlin
content: I remember @oaklandmatt saying in one of the lives that he uses a maxed of MBP as just a computer rather than as his workstation. Any problems with fan noise with your type of hybrid setup Matt?

author: chris_donlin
content:
What’s up people, the computer talk steered me in a good direction the other day. I realized a hybrid setup like @oaklandmatt  would be best for me. I can’t sacrifice portability :/ I narrowed it down to these two specs 

2.6GHz, 6 core - i7 processor, 32GB ram

Or 

2.3GHz, 8 core - i9, 32GB ram

Should I prioritize CPU or number of core processors? Any suggestions helps a ton! Appreciate you guys

author: ALXCPH
content: A completely different topic. Something that makes me scratch my head is when Jon keeps talking about how he hates compressors, and limiters and how he would literally cut off a finger just to keep every transient in the track(tongue in cheek). But then he uses a clipper at the end of his 2buss after a limiter. To basically cut them right off. I get that it works and I do it too. The science of it Still makes my head scratch tho. I guess I’m having a kind of existential transient crisis 😂 btw thank you @oaklandmatt n Jon for putting me on to spectre. It really is super dope.

author: Sam Melrod
content: @oaklandmatt and to all professionals with experience in the music business. If you have a business idea that is unique, and viable for this business, never done before, how do you navigate not telling the wrong people who might lift it in some form or fashion?

author: peterlabberton
content: I’m not @oaklandmatt , but, speaking for myself, yes! I definitely felt a lot of pressure when I was a staff engineer at a high-end studio, particularly because most clients were paying out of pocket. I did *not* want to give them a sub par experience or end product. More recently, I’ve gotten a manager and he’s been getting me significantly higher rates than I’ve gotten before. Kind of hate that it feels this way, but just having a higher number attached to my work makes me push just a little harder to make sure clients are getting their money’s worth.

author: spectrummasters
content: @oaklandmatt @BatMeckley ..thank you both for offering some perspective on it. I really appreciate it. To your point @BatMeckley , for where im at in my humble level of the hierarchy, the demo-itis thing has been a real handicap already with regard to what i wanted for a mix/production (its usually mostly with reverb on the vocals for me....I want it drier they want it soaked )  but then i watched Bainz on your live matt , post the Punk album release and he looked like he had PTSD for demoitis , so i figured its par for the course. Overall, i love recording so its not a chore, but sometimes it seems like the artist is getting in their own (and my "producers's) way)   and  so again, I really appreciate you both sharing your strategies for handling these moments.

author: spectrummasters
content:
Yes I defo get that and I agree with you . Moaning isn’t very rock star , smashing some shit on the other hand lol 

Im still undecided about the arguement that  streaming saved the industry from piracy that  Napster personnel made later (I need to check back on their names ) when one of them went on to be involved with Spotify I think  …..but I know there’s many arguements to be made in all directions . I enjoyed @oaklandmatt ‘s lwmr about the business side for a contemporary take on all This . My spicy take is streaming didn’t save the industry from collapse by piracy  …..the pirates maybe just captured the industry and held it to ransom to create streaming subscriptions

author: BatMeckley
content:
I mean, im not 100% speculating because I’ve gone through this with my friends (current) and with my pop (legacy). Basically they look at an average of the last 5 or so years, and then do a multiple of 10-15. Certain huge legacy names (Dylan, etc) they’ll go higher because it’s a loss leader to attract other artists to the fold. Numbers were bigger a before the last year or two before interests rates went up, because the catalogs were basically being bought by borrowed money.

As matt said, Irving has a long track record of making really smart business decisions both for himself and his artists, so I was curious if @SoundsLikeJoe had specific information regarding the financials of Rod’s catalog or if he was speculating.

author: Rollmottle
content: I think of an icon as having near universal appeal. None of the examples seem particularly compelling on that metric. Michael Jackson consumed a massive portion of the cultural oxygen. The time was also way different. Today you have superstars that are iconic to their fans and segments but I don’t see any “icons” as I’ve known them. Billie, Lana, TSwift, etc just don’t seem to have the same significance. Again, much different times…which I think I’m agreeing with @oaklandmatt

author: shaunobi
content:
Alright looks like a few “ifs” here, but there are several open-source model creators that we can use which will theoretically model dynamics. So, next steps will be to get three things working:
1) NAM
2) Proteus (cause maybe it sounds better)
3) that OG plugin

I’d recommend doing some kind of routing, even potentially out through a patchbay if necessary, and then “learning” the plugin. It doesn’t need to be on same computer though that would be simpler. 

@oaklandmatt were the settings on those plugins all different? Or did you kind of have a universal preset or three that you used?
